title: Shrine with Sumatinatha, the Fifth Jain Tirthankara

  title_text: Shrine with Sumatinatha
 the Fifth Jain Tirthankara

  preference: main

  creation_place_original_location: Gujarat (India)

  inscriptions:

  shape: irregular

  materials_name: silver (metal) copper (metal) bronze (metal)

  physical_appearance: This is a shrine of Sumatinatha
 the fifth Jain Tirthankara. There is a central figure in the middle of the shrine
 seated in meditation on a throne supported by two lions. The canopy of the throne is supported by a pair of elephants. The deity is accompanied by 23 other figures surrounding it. There are open-worked star-shaped patterns along the base of the shrine.

  subject_terms_1: Jainism deities worship

  subject_terms_2: Jainism Shrines Worship Ti?rthan?karas Gods

  subject_terms_3: Religious life and practices

  sgcool_label_text: Jains revere twenty-four Jinas
 who have attained a state of bliss and transcendence. Jina means “liberator” or “conqueror”. They help all creatures to liberate their souls from the confines of the body. Jinas are also called “river crossers” or “forders” (tirthankaras)
 because they have been released from the eternal cycle of rebirth.\r\n\r\nThis shrine contains a central image of Sumatinatha
 the fifth Jain Tirthankara
 identified by geese on the throne. He is believed to possess miraculous powers to fulfil the wishes of pilgrims. He is surrounded by the other twenty-three Jinas. The naked Jina’s indicate that the patrons of the temple for which this shrine was made were devoted to the Digambara sect.

metadata.title_text: Shrine with Sumatinatha, the Fifth Jain Tirthankara
metadata.physical_appearance: This is a shrine of Sumatinatha, the fifth Jain Tirthankara. There is a central figure in the middle of the shrine, seated in meditation on a throne supported by two lions. The canopy of the throne is supported by a pair of elephants. The deity is accompanied by 23 other figures surrounding it. There are open-worked star-shaped patterns along the base of the shrine.
metadata.sgcool_label_text:
Jains revere twenty-four Jinas, who have attained a state of bliss and transcendence. Jina means “liberator” or “conqueror”. They help all creatures to liberate their souls from the confines of the body. Jinas are also called “river crossers” or “forders” (tirthankaras), because they have been released from the eternal cycle of rebirth.

This shrine contains a central image of Sumatinatha, the fifth Jain Tirthankara, identified by geese on the throne. He is believed to possess miraculous powers to fulfil the wishes of pilgrims. He is surrounded by the other twenty-three Jinas. The naked Jina’s indicate that the patrons of the temple for which this shrine was made were devoted to the Digambara sect.
